text:
- Good morning, everyone!
We're having fish.

- We've just got the
headsail out at the moment.

I'm actually trying to slow
down which is something new.
- [Elayna] Where are we?
- We're in another land.

("They Wouldn't Want to
Know" by Airline Food)
- [Elayna] Last time,
here in the islands of Turks and Caicos,
we dropped off the parents
after an epic week sailing with them,

apart from of course,
Tony's fingers incident.
- Well, did you?
- [Elayna] You boys.
- [Riley] Ah Mr. and Mrs. Bond.
- [Elayna] Yeah.
(laughter)

- We also made a mad dash
to Barbados to apply for

our U.S. Visa so that we could
continue on our way northwest

through the Bahamas, and
eventually to Florida.

This morning, before we
planned to leave the country,

Riley was headed up the mast
to take care of a few jobs
he had been postponing for a while now.
- [Riley] How ya doin'?
- Stressing out big time.

("Four Seasons" by II
Chitarrista del SabatoPro)
Well, I'm glad that's over.

So we had to wait 'til
three p.m. to check out.
We wanted to check out at high tide
but customs refused to come and meet us.

We offered to go and find
them and come to them
wherever they were on the island

'cause we really wanted
to leave at high tide

and they said, "no, we'll see
you at the marina at three."
So we didn't have a choice.

So we checked out and left
as the tide was going down

and yeah, there wasn't much
depth between our rudders
and the ocean floor which is mostly rocks
so yeah, that was quite a narrow channel
that I was pretty nervous going through

'cause you have to go
right through the middle

'cause there's like high reef
either side, but I made it.
And we're out. And it feels good. (laughs)
(ocean waves)
- [Riley] Alright, pantaloons.
You did a very, very good job.
Who's my little helmsman? Ay?
Yeah...
No, that's quite...
hectic.
I understand.

Getting blown off course,
trying to dodge markers
and reef and all different sorts of stuff.
- My heart's just calmed down so
I'm treating myself to a black bean soup
which looks like absolute.
- [Riley] What about my baby?
You didn't stress out my baby, did ya?
- I hope not.

- [Riley] I might make
you a chamomile tea.
- Alright.
- We just exiting the last of the markers

and came out of the reef and
we're able to calm down a bit.
- [Elayna] Yeah, so I can breathe again.
- We're in deep water.
There's a lot of water underneath the cube

which is
- [Elayna] Thank goodness.
- That's great news.
- [Elayna] I love that.
- So, we were gonna go down...
or up west, east of the island

and tack up and try
and get a mooring board

but once we came outside
the reef, we realised that

with the direction of
the wind and the swell

that it was gonna be
very unpleasant there.
So we decided to head to Ack-land Island,
or Acklins Island which is 100 miles away.
In these conditions, you'd normally have

the full mainsail up, maybe
one reef, probably not
and the head sail, and I thought,

oh we'll just head down wind
and 'cause we're not really,
we're actually trying to go quite slow

so we'll just wind the
head sail and take it easy
and we're doing eight knots.

We're absolutely fine.
- So we're gonna get there
too early.

- So we're probably gonna
get there too early.

We might have to wreath the
head sail, trynna slow her down.
And it's comfortable as.
It must be a four knot current.
Escapade, Vagabonde, go ahead.
- [Radio] Roger, one, four.
- Roger, one, four.
- Roger that mate, how are you?
- We are, yeah.

We're just heading in
that general direction.
- [Elayna] What was that?
- No mate, common misconception.

We certainly weren't
given a boat. (laughs)
- [Elayna] I wish!

- Wouldn't that be
lovely if that was true.
(Elayna laughs)

Yeah. Yeah. No, probably as
much our fault as anyones.
(ocean waves)

I'm a bit lonely. Elayna's
asleep at the moment.
She's been getting more seasick
sort of basically as the years go on

but also especially
since she's been pregnant
and I'm much more inclined to just go,
well no, like go and rest,

and that was the advice
that we were given, as well.

But it just means that
I've had to sail a bit more
which is fine but I have found like
I've been getting fairly fatigued at sea

which happened when I
got into Providenciales

and I know I'm not gonna be
able to sleep too much tonight.
I mean, the sailing is not difficult.

We've just got the
headsail out at the moment.

I'm actually trynna slow
down which is something new.

Just the lack of sleep,
I've been finding it
more difficult to deal with more recently.
And hats off to the single handed sailors,
you guys are just mad-dogs.
(ocean waves)
We've arrived quite early in the morning.
We wanna try and go through the channel
when the sun is high in the sky
so the we can see the reef on either side
so I'm just trying to kill a bit of time.

So I'm just heading North and
then I'm gonna go south again
and just blow a couple of hours.
It is eight in the morning.

I'd like to go through about
11 - 10:30, something like that
just because we haven't been there before

There's another boat in
there, which is a catamaran.
We've read all the guide books
and it looks to be a fairly...
clear-cut entrance so

that's good but we'll just
play it very cautiously

considering we ran aground on
the first island back there.
We don't want to do that again.
I should be being a bit more quiet

because Elayna's having a
bit of a sleep over here.
Darling, sweet Elayna.

("Superficial Spectacle"
by Sea Foam Sweater Girl)
- Morning, everyone! We're havin' fish.
- [Riley] Get me the net?
- Yeah.
- [Riley] Okay
Ah, it's a little tuna.
- [Elayna] Yeah.
- [Riley] Excellent.
- There's no better way to wake up than...

to a fish, because it has to
be fast, you're always excited,
and you just don't have a choice,

you just can't be lying
around, it's just--
- [Riley] It's like a squall.

- All hands on deck.
It's like a squall, yeah.
But we have a little skipjack tuna.
- [Riley] Squall!

And we were gonna share
it with our neighbours

but they're leaving so -
- It's a squall!

I'm just following the guy
that was in the harbour

He's leaving so I'm just
following his track.
where the iOS is showing that he is,
I can see where he went on the way out.

14 metres long, eight metre
beam, so fairly similar to us.
Definitely a catamaran going at six knots
out of the anchorage.
I think that we could easily get in there.
All of these little bits of information

add up to a slightly safer
trip, don't they, (mumbles)?
- [Elayna] They do.
This has been the worst trip I've had
in very, very long time.

I've just been like so
nauseous. I haven't slept.

There's been many dashes
to the back of the boat.

I just cannot wait to, get off
this boat right now honestly.
It's no fun...
feeling this way.
Riley's just navigating to the reef now
and we should be there so

not long, I think we've got
about like 10 minutes left.
("Devil Like Me" cover by Elayna C)
- [Riley] This is Atwood Harbour.

There's only 600 or so people
living here on the island
and after the sponge diving dwindled

after the advent of synthetics,
the inhabitants now live
by fishing and very small scale farming.

♪ Holes riddle in your
head, little bit of lead ♪
Oh my God, it's Elayna.
Where have you been?
- Dead.
(Riley snorts)

- [Riley] You remember
the bit where you go,
"Get me off this boat!"
- That's what I said.
(Riley laughs)
I hated the boat.

Thanks for sailing us
all this way, (mumbles).
- It's alright.
(Elayna laughs)

Thanks for spending 10
minutes making me lunch.

- [Elayna] You're welcome.
It was really hard work.
What are you doing?
- That was just so funny.
I went over to the boat in front of us.

Basically, they looked
like they're on the run.

There's like, two dogs
jump up out of their boat
and just start barking like anything
so I gave 'em a little bit of tuna.
I was like, alright there's two bits here,

do you want both or
are you happy with one?

And he was like, "go on,
give 'em both," to me.
So I was like, "No worries, mate."
and I gave them both to him and then
I said, "where have you been?"
He said, "Oh, I've been at Little Inagua."
He goes, "It's so good there.
"I didn't see a soul for four months."
(Elayna laughs)
("Un-friend" by Ronjo V)

- So we've decided on an
afternoon cruise up the river.

It's actually, it's not a
river, it's water, it's a sea
(Riley singing)

It's a sea, and like, so, and
the water's nice and blue.
It's very shallow.
We don't know where the reef is

because there was nothing
marked on our navigation.
- [Riley] (mumbles) through here.

There would definitely be
crabs here and mosquitoes.

- [Elayna] A lot of
mosquitoes. Oh, I can see fish!
Oh my God! Where are we?
- We're in another land.

That's about as good
as we could have hoped.
(Elayna laughs)

♪ So don't be long. I get
this feeling, I'm gone. ♪
- [Elayna] Alright, who have we got here
and what's going on?

- These guys are running
very low on diesel
so we've agreed to share.

It's about time we help
someone else out, Elayna.
- Yeah.

We met this young couple
on the beach last night
and they really made us laugh.
They were telling us a few stories

and it really reminds Riley
and I of when we first started

so Riley just phoned over
and asked if we could

come over with the camera and
interview them for you guys
so that's what we're about to do.

- As soon as the dingy shows
up, he just stands over here,

waiting for someone to
let him jump into it.
(laughter)
- Ben and Meghan Visser, on Loose Seal.
That's not the name Lucille.
It's the words "loose" and "seal".
- A seal who has gotten loose.
- An animal that
- [Elayna] Oooh, I like it.
- has gotten loose.
It's a British boat.
It's a Camper Nicholson. It's 1979 80.
Thirty four and a half foot boat

and it's got a Volkswagen
Rabbit diesel engine in it.

- [Elayna] And what made you
embark on this wild adventure?

- Our story is really that
we got a really cheap boat

and y'know worked on it
for a month in the yard
and we were totally clueless in terms of
what we actually needed to do.
- Well, we put it in the water

and we had to take it out
like a month after. (laughs)
- A couple months later, yeah.
It was leaking from below the water line,
so we had to get it hauled out.

- And you always imagine
that it's just gonna take

no time at all and you'll
be in the beautiful waters.

- Oh yeah, we thought we
were going to Grenada.
(laughter)
- It's a good little reality check.
- [Elayna] Did you have any clue
about sailing before you set off?
- I've been sailing for about 10 years
but just on smaller boats.

We had a little 20 foot
trailer sailor in Chicago.

- He bought the 20 foot boat
a week before our wedding.

- Yeah, I was still making
my own financial decisions.
(laughter)
- Hilarious.
- We just kinda jumped into it.
- Yeah.
- It's been amazing.
- Yeah.

- It's been an adventure. It's
been challenging at times.

- [Elayna] Okay, if you
had any advice to give

to people who were
thinking about starting up
also not having a clue about sailing.
- Well, just do it.

It kinda felt like it was a
now or never decision for us
and so we, so, just go for it.
- Yeah.
- You'll figure it out.

- Just make it happen.
- Well said, guys.

- [Elayna] Alright. Well
thank you both so much.
- Yeah, thanks for

stopping by, you guys.
- You're welcome, of course.
- [Elayna] No worries!
("Home" by Hollow Coves)
So, we're about to light a fire

and everyone's on log-hunting
duty. Oh, and so is Mason!
Get the stick! Get the Stick!
Go on. Get the stick! Get it!
(Elayna laughs) Oh! Nice (mumbles)
- It's a six-corner Jack.

- Alright, I should
probably start helping now,

put the camera down, time
to get my hands dirty.
♪ To the friends I've always known. ♪
Well, we just got back from the beach.
We had a fire with our friends
and yeah, so Terry who was over here today
who grabbed some of our diesel,

he also had a hard drive filled
with like a million movies

so we just spent the afternoon
transferring all those

over onto our hard
drive so we're just like

so excited right now
having so many options,

but (mumbles) from Tangaroa
also made Riley some bread

which doesn't look like much
now but we just toasted it
and it was like the best bread ever.
- It's the best bread that I've had since

Lorraine Mills used to make
me bread back in (mumbles).
- [Elayna] Okay.
(water sloshing)
- [Riley] Good morning, pantalons.
- Good morning.
- [Riley] How are ya doing?
- Good. Had the best sleep ever.
As you guys know,

it's really hard for
me to sleep on the boat
and that's been getting worse and worse
as I get older for some odd reason

so the lack of sleep's
really been getting to me.

Also, just being away
from friends and family

all the time like it's
basically just been me and Riley
for four years now and obviously,

we meet people on the way,
we become really good friends

but we're always
separating again so I just,

I don't have that sense of
community, which I really love
and then also recently, becoming pregnant,

I guess the sea sickness has
been getting a bit worse.
I've still been pretty lucky.

Like I haven't been y'know
bed-ridden and just totally sick

but I'm nauseous and that makes
me not want to do anything

and then I gotta lay
down and I feel terrible
for Riley who's got to sail like,

I hate laying down and
watching him do all the work,

like I do not enjoy that at
all and I feel helpless and
yeah, I guess I'm going through
a bit of a tough time at the moment.

I don't want to stop what I'm
doing, but, it's just, yeah.
It's just pretty tough. Do you concur?

- Well, it's funny. Like, I
think, normal couples would
have a kid and then be like, alright,
well one person's gotta stop working

and how are we gonna
make all of this happen

so I think it's all
pretty normal apart from
we're in a, quite a odd
and, at times, really difficult situation.

- I feel grateful that
it's gonna be both of us

that get to spend the 100
percent of the time with the baby
like not many people get to do that.
- Mm.
- So that's gonna be amazing.
- I think that ongoing, like long-term,
it's been more, like you said,

not having your mates
around and I'm the same.

I really, really miss my
mates back in Adelaide,
friends and family and whatnot.
Maybe with the baby around,
it'll be more of a little family.

- Yeah. It'll be good when
it could start talking.

(laughs) 'Til then it's
still me and you really.
- Just you, me, and the little football

sitting there and not doing
anything, 'cept crying.
(Elayna laughs)

- But yeah, we're clearly
going through one of those
phases of indecision which I'm sure
every couple is faced with at about the,
at the end of the first trimester.

So I'd really like to ask
everyone out there what you think?

What would you do? What
would you do in my situation?
What advice would you give Elayna?

Would you slow down doing what
we're doing? Would you stop?

Beyond than just, "Oh,
it's going to be harder
"when the baby's there."
I mean, we know that,

but what specific advice
would you give us?

I'm really interested
to troll through that

and see if I can find any
nuggets of gold in there.
Awesome guys. Thanks for watching. Cheers.

- [Elayna] Next week,
join us as we continue

our journey through the
Bahamas and see the reason why

we're deciding to stay
here, possibly forever.
Man, this water's insane!
("Home" by Hollow Coves)
